A B S T R A C T

Despite intensive research in recent years, the biosynthetic route to costunolide in sunflower so far remained obscured. Additional P450 sequences from public sunflower transcriptomic database were screened to search for candidate enzymes which are able to introduce the 6α-hydroxy-group required for the esterification with the carboxy group of germacarane A acid, the final step in costunolide formation. CYP71BL9, a new P450 enzyme from sunflower was shown to catalyze this hydroxylation, hence being identified as HaCOS. Phylogentically, HaCOS is closer related to HaG8H than to any other known costunolide synthase in Asteraceae .The enzyme was successfully employed to reconstruct the sunflower biosynthesis of costunolide in transformed tobacco. Contrary, in yeast, only minor amounts of sesquiterpene lactone was produced, while 5-hydroxyfarnesylic acid was formed instead. HaCOS in combination with HaG8H produced 8β-hydroxycostunolide (eupatolide) in transformed plants, thus indicating that sunflower possesses two independent modes of eupatolide synthesis via HaCOS and via HaES. The lack of HaCOS expression and of costunolide in trichomes suggests that the enzyme triggers the costunolied synthesis of the inner tissues of sunflower and might be linked to growth regulation processes.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
2.1. Gene identification and phylogenetic analysis
sec.p:
Previously, from the cDNA of
Helianthus annuus
cv. HA300 several candidate genes were described that had a similar expression pattern in a public transcriptome database (Heliagene). This led to the characterization of the
Helianthus annuus
eupatolide synthase (
). We found in this database one accession that had a similar expression pattern to HaGAO. This gene was predominantly expressed in leaves and bracts and had a high sequence similarity to both HaG8H (the only so far characterized CYP71BL enzyme from sunflower) and to the costunolide synthases from
Tanacetum
and other Asteraceae species. Using 5′and 3′RACE PCR we identified the whole open reading frame and the UTR regions of this gene, that was officially assigned CYP71BL9 (http://drnelson.uthsc.edu/cytochromeP450.html). The CYP71BL subfamily comprises only genes that use germacrene A acid as a substrate. In this group, CYP71BL9 clustered together with the
H. annuus
germacrene A acid 8β-hydroxylase HaG8H (CYP71BL1), but clearly separated from yet characterized costunolide synthases ( Fig. 1 ).

sec.title: 2.2. Reconstruction of the costunolide biosynthesis in Nicotiana benthamiana
sec.p:
The biosynthetic pathway of germacrene A acid was recently resonstructed in
Nicotiana benthamiana
using the native sunflower enzymes HaGAS1 and HaGAO (
,
). Ten enzyme candidates from
H. annuus
were now tested downstream of germacrene A acid and the
Lactuca sativa
costunolide synthase LsCOS (CYP71BL2) was used as a positive control. The expression of the candidate gene CYP71BL9 [p19/DXS + HaGAS1 + HaGAO + CYP71BL9] led to two major peaks (peak a , 9.00 min) and (peak b , 9.15 min), that were absent in the negative control [p19/DXS + HaGAS1 + HaGAO] ( Fig. 2A ). The masses and UV spectra of peak a and b indicated that these peaks could be the SH adducts costunolide-cysteine and costunolide-glutathione Fig..2B–D ). Indeed, comparison of retention time, exact mass and mass spectrum with synthetic adducts identified these peaks as costunolide-cysteine and costunolide-glutathione (peak a and b in Fig. S1 and Fig. S2 ). Free costunolide ( c **,14.18 min in Fig. 2A ) was only detected in trace amounts. In general, the production of costunolide (and its SH adducts) by CYP71BL9 was higher than in the control experiment with LsCOS. While both LsCOS and CYP71BL9 converted GAA to costunolide in planta , the composition of the costunolide derivatives was different, with LsCOS producing relatively less contunolide-glutathione ( Fig. S3 ). The costunolide-glutathione peak produced by LsCOS could only be deduced from the extracted ion chromatogram (peak b *). The generation of glutathione and cysteine conjugates with α-methylene-γ-lactones as well as other unspecific reactions in
Nicotiana benthamiana
has been widely reported and the underlying mechanisms are well understood (
).

sec.p: 2.4. Expression of CYP71BL 9 in yeast

When CYP71BL9 was expressed together with the substrate vector for GAA [Leu2d:GAS/GAO/CR| Ura:CYP71BL9], a new product (peak a, 10.19 min, λ max = 204 nm ) appeared in HPLC analysis in comparison to the negative control [Leu2d:GAS/GAO/CR| Ura:empty] (data not shown). When CYP71BL9 was expressed downstream of 8β-OH-GAA [Leu2d:GAS/GAO/CR/HaG8H|Ura:CYP71BL9], peak a was still detected together with a second peak (peak b , 15.5 min, λ max = 207 nm ) ( Fig. 4A ). A small amount of peak b could be collected from the HPLC runs. It showed the same retention time and absorption spectrum as the costunolide standard ( Fig. 4B ). The identity of the purified peak b with costunolide was confirmed by MS-MS spectra ( Fig 4 ,D-E) and 1H NMR analysis. Peak a was purified by preparative HPLC . NMR analysis and comparison of NMR data to a structurally similar farnesyl lactone (
) identified the compound as 5-hydroxyfarnesylic acid. The formation of this side product may be caused by a reaction of farnesol with CYP71BL9. The underlying reaction mechanism remains unclear, however.

sec.title: 3. Conclusions
sec.p:
In our study we have characterized the
Helianthus annuus
costunolide synthase HaCOS (CYP71BL9) that converted germacrene A acid to costunolide, the commonly presumed precursor of a wide range of STL. Our results will fuel the elucidation of biosynthetic routes downstream of costunolide in sunflower and related species of the Heliantheae tribe and the understanding of the physiological role of costunolide and DCL in sunflower.

4.3. Characterization of enzyme products by HPLC NMR spectroscopy and
mass spectrometry
sec.p:
Extracts from yeast cultures were analyzed by HPLC-DAD (Prominence system Shimadzu Germany GmbH, Duisburg) with a Kromasil C18 column (100 18C, 25 cm × 4 mm x 5 μm particle size; MZ Analysentechnik, Mainz, Germany ). After the injection of 80 μl (corresponding to 2 mL culture volume), extracts were separated using the following program: min 40–100 B, 1 min 100 B, 4 min 40 B; A:ddH 2 O/ 0.01% TFA B: ACN, 1 ml/min). 5-hydroxyfarnesylic acid and costunolide were purified from yeast cultures by HPLC and anylzed by NMR spectroscopy and mass spectrometry. NMR spectrometry was conducted with a 500 MHz Varian Unity Inova (Varian, Inc./Agilent Technologies, Palo Alto, CA, USA ) spectrometer with a 3 mm ID PFG probe in 3 mm NMR vials. Spectra were referenced to the solvent signal of chloroform (δH/C 7.27/77 ppm). For a full structural analysis, 1H NMR, 1D TOCSY and several 2D spectra were recorded (gCOSY, gHSQAD, gHMBCAD, ROESY, NOESY, TOCSY). For mass spectrometry the purified compound was re-run on a LC-MS system with Agilent (Waldbronn, Germany ) 1290 UHPLC on a HSS T3 column (1.8 μm particle size, 50 mm × 2.1 mm , Waters, Dublin , Ireland ) in combination with a quadrupole mass spectrometer (QTRAP 5500, LC-MS/MS system (AB Sciex Instruments, Darmstadt, Germany ) Q3-MS, ESI-pos. Screening of extracts from
Nicotiana benthamiana
with putative enzyme products, and comparison of enzyme products to synthetic adducts was conducted using LC-MS as previously described (
).
